2025 | 2 Months | UE5 | PC | 12-person team | 3D | Couch Game
2025 | 1 Month | UE5 | PC | 9-person team | 3D | First Person | Horror Game

During the concept design stage, I shaped the cave environment as a place where nature and luminescence intertwine — overgrown with vegetation and crystals — to reflect the expedition’s story and enhance the eerie, enigmatic mood.

For the vegetation modeling, I used alpha-textured planes to reduce the polygon count and optimize game performance. 

In the concept, the cave’s ecosystem is designed to be mysterious and diverse, so I created plants with highly saturated colors. This not only adds vibrant accents to the dark environment but also subtly enhances the eerie atmosphere.
With the pixel post-processing in Unreal Engine, the rendering looks like much better and finally fits our art direction.
I also designed interactive props such as containers and flasks. When thrown and shattered glass tube, the sound activates nearby crystals, providing temporary light for navigation.

During the game's promotional phase, I created the studio and game logos, as well as the promotional posters. Typically, I also adapt marketing assets to different platforms, adjusting their sizes and styles to best fit each website’s requirements.
2025 | 1 Month | Unity | Mobile | 9-person team | 2D |  Puzzle Game
2025 | Game Jam | 48 h | PC | Unity | 2-person team | Rhythm Game

We decided to create a dating simulation combined with a rhythm game, so I set the scene in a bar to provide a natural setting for the dating dialogue. 

To make the most of the limited time, I used large color blocks and simplified shapes to quickly produce clear and effective visual materials during the brainstorming phase.
For character design, I used a flat, cartoon style without outlines. This approach keeps the visuals clean while making it easier to separate elements for animation.
2025 | Game Jam | 4 days | PC | UE5 | 12-person team | 3D | Adventure Game

During the concept art phase, I set the environment in a factory where the doors are manufactured. This setting aligns with the dark and mysterious tone typical of the SCP universe, while also providing a logical foundation for the game’s “multiple doors” concept.

I independently designed the art direction for the game’s main menu, covering everything from modeling and materials to layout, lighting, and UI. 

I believe the main menu is one of the most important parts of a game because it gives players their first impression and sets the overall tone. That is why I dedicated significant time and attention to perfecting it.
2025 | Game Jam | 4 days | PC | Godot Engine | 4-person team | Narrative Game

To simplify the art production process and reduce development difficulty, I chose pixel art as the main style. This allowed me to create a variety of characters in a short time, enriching the overall game content.

The menu design was completely a random event. I really liked the game’s story script, so I casually drew an illustration of the two main characters in my free time. Then I suddenly thought—why not use it as the menu background? And that’s how the current menu came to be :)
2024 | Game Jam | 4 days | Unity | PC | 4-person team | 2D | FPS

For this project, I was responsible for designing one of the enemy characters. The style follows the main visual direction with white fill, black outlines, and a vintage cartoon aesthetic. In the enemy’s animation, arrows shoot out from its eyes, and its death ends with a small explosion.
These are promotional assets I created, along with some in-game materials.
2024 | Game Jam | 48h | PC | Unity | 5-person team | Roguelike

The art direction of InkRebels is set in a medieval style, so for the enemy designs I drew inspiration from medieval legends, such as anti-religious demons and knights blinded by heresy. Visually, I used highly decorative brushwork and color to emulate the look and feel of medieval hand-painted illustrations.
We didn’t have much time to create elaborate decorations, so I focused on reusing the same basic assets to maximize variation.

I’ve always thought the main menu is an important part of a game and a great place to get creative. In InkRebels, I set the menu in an old medieval book, so starting the game feels like flipping through pages and discovering the story, which fits the theme perfectly since the character is an ink blot trying to escape the book.
With the leaderboard, we could see every player’s score, which made the game feel much more interactive.

I also left a spot in the bottom right corner for the team to sign. It was a really enjoyable team experience, and I’m really happy that I could keep a trace of every lovely teammate who contributed to the game.

A psychological horror game set in a sound-reactive cave where light and danger coexist. Players must balance visibility and silence to survive.
I directed the artistic vision and created the environmental concept art, then handled vegetation modeling, texturing, materials, 
and in-engine rendering in Unreal Engine 5.

A medieval dark-themed card puzzle game where players must eliminate all sacrifices in a single turn to feed a demon. 
Each level is a 12-tile card puzzle that challenges strategic use of limited powers.
I led the art direction and created all 2D assets, including cards, interface, and menu UI.

For the card designs in Damned Devotion, I took inspiration from medieval mythology and traditional tarot aesthetics to establish a mystical, era-appropriate visual language.

When designing the characters on the cards, I paid close attention to historical accuracy, carefully avoiding modernized or anachronistic elements in costumes, accessories, and overall styling. This helped maintain a cohesive and believable atmosphere throughout the game.

From a UX perspective, I introduced a clear visual distinction between different card types through their frame designs. Functional cards (cards players can interact with) feature more ornate and decorative borders, emphasizing their importance and inviting engagement. 

Non-movable cards have simplified, less embellished frames, subtly communicating their passive role within the game environment.

To match the game’s vintage art direction, 
I aged the cards and refined the color palette, while introducing visual hierarchy in the UI to strengthen overall cohesion.
To further align with the art direction, I incorporated additional religious motifs into the designs, reinforcing the game’s ritualistic atmosphere while maintaining visual cohesion.
For the UI design, I followed the same visual style, incorporating consistent skull motifs to strengthen the overall design language.

In the menu design, I incorporated various medieval decorative elements to enrich the visual diversity. I am passionate about adding details, and for every UI element, I strive to find its own unique visual identity.

Game Jam theme: "Few seconds, an eternity."

We chose to tell a love story that captures the idea of love at first sight — a moment that lasts only a few seconds yet feels eternal.
During the jam, I worked as the sole game artist, creating all of the visual assets for the game.

Game Jam theme: "SCP - 004"

Inspired by the twelve rusty metal keys from SCP-004, we created an exploration puzzle game centered around the concept of doors. My main work included creating 2D concept art, importing 3D assets into Unreal Engine 5, setting up the in-engine environments, and producing promotional visuals for the project.

Game Jam theme : "Fxxking Capitalism"

This was my first time participating in a game jam with a randomly formed online team of strangers. Coincidentally, all of us turned out to be young Chinese women from different parts of the world (well, except China itself, haha). So, we decided to create a story centered around feminine power and resistance against capitalism.
In this project, I served as the Art Director, responsible for the overall art direction and project management. I also handled character design, animation, and UI illustration.

This project was a valuable experience in learning how to collaborate with game designers and programmers using Git. Since we only had 4 days to complete it, I consider it a game jam project. 
I was one of the two artists on the team, responsible for environment design, part of the animations, and the creation of promotional artwork.

“What can we actually achieve in just four days?” — that’s the question 
I always ask myself before every game jam.

This time, I decided to go with a vintage Disney-inspired 2D cartoon style, paired with a monochromatic main color palette. It keeps the project stylish while also keeping the workload manageable.

I enjoy the challenge of achieving maximum visual impact with minimal resources, and I believe this was a successful attempt.
Concept Art in Procreate                    Rendering in Unity

This is quite a challenging shooting game, 
have a nice try and good luck !

Ludum Dare 56 was the first game jam I joined. Although the game has many flaws in hindsight, it was a big step in my game development journey and I learned a lot.

I was one of two artists, mainly responsible for art direction, some character design and animation, as well as menu and UI design. Notably, the project ranked in the top 14% for visual art (281e/1929e) and received numerous positive feedback, making it an encouraging start to my journey in the game industry !
Try to play and enjoy your game !  :)
